Combined enhanced oil recovery (EOR) methods have been proposed to benefit from several simultaneous mechanisms. The application of nanoparticles and carbonated water have been studied in recent years. In this study, Axisymmetric Drop Shape Analysis (ADSA) was applied to investigate the ability of a hybrid technique – i.e., the simultaneoususe of TiO2,MgO, andγ-Al2O3 nanoparticles and carbonated formationwater as an available water source in reducing interfacial tension (IFT) as a main EOR mechanism. To achieve this goal, the initial and 10 diluted samples of formation water were selected as the base fluids. The nanoparticles were dispersed at concentrations of 500 and 1000 ppm in the base fluids and were stabilized using ultrasonic waves. Carbon dioxide was applied to the system at temperatures of 40, 60, and 80 °C and pressures of 0.10, 6.89, and 13.79 MPa. In this way, the effects of salinity, nanoparticle concentration, temperature, and pressure were investigated on IFT values in carbonated nanofluid injection. The results show that the combination of these two methods has a significant effect on the reduction of IFT. In addition, the IFT between carbonated nano-fluids and crude oil shows a direct relationship with the temperature and salinity of the base fluid and reverse relationship with the concentration of nanoparticles and the pressure.

1. Introduction
Integrating the enhanced oil recovery (EOR) techniques is a common practice to promote and correct one or several EOR methods. An ideal EOR process is the one that takes all its components to a point where it can lead to further loss of remaining saturated oil content. Sometimes, minor goals are also pursued in an EOR operation. For example, in a different type of injection of carbon dioxide, in addition to an increase in oil extraction, a greenhouse gas storage in a hydrocarbon reservoir may occur, which may not be the main purpose of the operation. In this regard, Zendehboudi et al. investigated a newmethod of insitu dissolving carbon dioxide in the aquifer to prevent CO2 leakage and low rates of carbon dioxide dissolution in brine [1].

Reducing interfacial tension (IFT) betweenwater and oil in chemical water injection process is a very important and effective factor in reducing the capillary pressure and, as a result, increasing the rate of oil recovery. Chemical surfactants are well suited for IFT reduction to the extent necessary for expanded operations, but in addition to the technicality of the injection of surfactants, economic feasibility should also be considered. Economic feasibility is fundamentally dependent on various parameters such as oil prices and the cost of surfactants [2]. Thus, problems such as the cost of these products, benchmarking, and feasibility of improving the injection of water by cheaper materials should be considered in this regard. Regulating the ions in smart water and the use of water-soluble carbon dioxide are methods that reduce the IFT [3]. Esene et al. investigated the carbonate water injection method based on the concentration of CO2, salinity, injection pressure, temperature, and injection rate, as important operational conditions that affect theperformance of the carrbonatedwater injection process in particular [4]. Carbonated water and carbonated smart water are commonly used withmechanisms such as reducing the IFT, altering the reservoir's rocks wettability, reducing viscosity and oil swelling through the transfer of carbon dioxide from carbonated water to adjacent oil, and increasing
the viscosity of injected water to improve the sweep efficiency for reducing the oil remains and enhancing the oil recovery [5–9].
The use of carbonatedwater is a solution to increase the efficiency of carbon dioxide injection, which includes the mechanisms involved; however, it also has a disadvantage when it comes to storing carbon dioxide. The carbon dioxide solubility inwater is typically higher than that of other gases, but in carbonated water injection in reservoirs, less carbon dioxide is injected than direct carbon dioxide injection. However, the mechanisms of this method are often directly influenced by the amount of carbon dioxide dissolved in water. In addition to optimizing the base fluid salinity, adjusting the temperature and pressure of the injection fluid can increase the solubility. Increasing the solubility of carbon dioxide in water by conventional and inexpensive nanoparticles can also be a solution to this challenge. Unlike other dissolved solids, dispersed nanoparticles in water can increase the solubility of carbon dioxide by surface adsorption [10–12].
Moreover, the reports of the use of nanoparticles as an advanced knowledge in EOR show that nano-fluids are effective in reducing the IFT between oil and injected phase. The use of nano-fluids, also known as smart nano-fluids, in EOR is structured in two sections of the base fluid and nanoparticle [13]. In the past, due to the expensiveness and complexity of the production of nanoparticles, they were not widely used in petroleum industry. But, today, with the advancement of nanoscience and new technologies in this field, and considering high efficiency of this method, the problem is almost eliminated and nanoenhanced oil recovery (NEOR) method has received much attention a useful and effectivemethod. NEOR is normally combinedwith chemical methods such as simultaneous use with surfactants [14–17], smart water in high and low salinity [18,19], injection as carbonated water [20], gas [21], foam [22], and polymers [23,24]. Nano-fluid mechanisms in EORmainly include reduction of IFT [14,25,26], wettability alteration [27–29], heavy oil swelling [30], asphaltene stability [13,31], oil viscosity reduction [32–34], increasing the viscosity of the injected phase [35,36], creating nano-emulsion [37], pore channel plugging [38,39], and disjoining pressure. In this regard, the disjoining pressure mechanism has high interaction with other issues such as wettability alteration [40–42].
Many studies have beenundertaken onwater-oil IFT changes by carbonated water and nanoparticles dispersed in injected fluids. Table 1 lists some of these studies. Reducing IFT by carbonated water is normally not enough to reduce capillary pressure, while a significant
reduction by nanofluids has been reported. Addition of nanoparticles to carbonated water may lead to some increase in carbonated water injection efficiency, probably due to the following issues: 1) a further carbon dioxide storage and 2) a further reduction in IFT.
In this work, the effects of TiO2, MgO, and γ-Al2O3 nanoparticles in carbonated formation water on reducing the IFT were studied using the pendant drop method. Moreover, the effects of parameters such as nanoparticle concentration, pressure, temperature, and base fluid salinity were evaluated.
2. Materials and equipment
2.1. Crude oil
Dead crude oil from Karanj reservoir in Iran with an API gravity of 32.02 was used. Crude oil components are reported in Table 2.
2.2. Saline water
The salinewater from Karanj reservoir in Iranwas used in this study as a water-forming material with a pH of 7.23. The species obtained from water titration are listed in Table 3.
2.3. Carbon dioxide, nitrogen and acetone
Carbon dioxide and nitrogen were purchased from Abughaddareh Industrial Gases Co. Iran, with a purity of 99.99 mole% and a primary pressure of 2.7 MPa. Acetone was purchased from MP-Biomedical Netherlands Company with a purity of 99.9 mole%.
2.4. Nano-particles
The TiO2, MgO, and γ-Al2O3 nanoparticles were purchased from USNano America Inc. and were used with the specifications given in Table 4. Fig. 1 presents TEM images of nanoparticles.
2.5. Interfacial tension measurement equipment
IFT400 (Fars EOR Technologies Co. Iran) was used to carry out IFT tests. The basis of this device is the pendant drop method and the use of Axisymmetric Drop Shape Analysis (ADSA) to measure the IFT. This
equipment consists of two bulk and drip fluid hand pumps that are also used for pressure regulation, a drop valve equipped with three thermal elements and two glass valves, one against the adjustable lighting bar and the other against the CCD camera (HD, 2Mega Pixels), Temperature and Pressure Indicators and Controllers, High Pressure Valves, 2.05mm Drop Metal Needle Blowers, and a computer equipped with software. With a tolerance of up to 20 MPa and a precision of 0.5% full scale, the maximum allowable temperature is up to 180 °C with a precision of ±0.3 °C. Drop tubes are filled with bubble fluid by a special pump, which is pumped by the user and the oil droplet by a mutual pump in the bulk fluid from the tip of the needle. The experiments of this study were based on the difference in the density of oil and base water fluids and their clarity for transparency of drop, placed in the bottom of the compartment. The camera provides the droplet image to the software for processing, and the software reports the IFT at any moment.
The three thermoelectric heaters fitted in the body of the tubes provide the required heat and a PT-100 thermocouple regulates the temperature after optimization of the PID controller parameters. The device should be carefully washed before and after each test with solvents such as acetone and water and dried with nitrogen gas. To ensure the accuracy, the device should bewashed properly and IFT tests should be conducted for systems such as water-air and water-toluene, which have certain values. Items such as a metal needle and ground wire are attached to this device. In addition to obtaining the correct data from the device, other than observing the principles of washing, controlling the proper conditions of the hanging drops, such as the size of the droplet is sufficient, symmetrical, and constant. Ultimately, the software shows IFT with an uncertainty of ±0.2–0.5 mN/m. The IFT400 has the ability to connect the gas cylinder and the ability to make carbonated water at temperatures and pressures permitted by the device in its
own cell. For this purpose, the connection between the pumps and the drip of the inlet valve of the gas connection is embedded and the nitrogen cylinder is used for circulation of the gas in the device for drying after washing. Fig. 2 illustrates the schematic of this device.

The system used for the preparation of carbonatedwater at different temperatures and pressures includes a cylinder and a piston made of stainless steel, linked from the bottom by a high-pressure line to an oil hydraulic pump and from the top to the associated gas cylinder. The cylinder also has two upper and lower gates. The entire cylinder and piston system is mounted on an oven of the UFE 400 model manufactured by Memert Germany. A valve is placed on the line of pressure connected to the gas cylinder to disconnect and connect it. The initial fluid is introduced into the cylinder and after the upper lid is closed, carbon dioxide gas is introduced. After adding carbon dioxide to the system, the gas inlet valve is closed and after applying the temperature, the pressure of the system is supplied by lifting the piston by a manual hydraulic pump and controlled by a pressure gauge, which is controlledmanually by a cylinder and hydraulic pump connected. The high-pressure line connected to carbon dioxide is separated from the gas cylinder when the valve is closed. In this case, the carbonatedwaterwill be transmitted to the devices used for further experiments. In all stages, the pressure and temperature of carbonated water are controlled, all parts are washed with water and acetone and dried with high-pressure nitrogen gas, and the embedded O-rings in the upper gate and the bottom of the cylinder and the piston are assured to be safe. The schematic of the carbonated water supply system at various pressures and temperatures is presented in Fig. 3.
2.7. Density measurement equipment
The high temperature and pressure DMAHPMdensitymeter (Anton Paar, Austria) was used for measuring the density of fluids and carbonated nano-fluids in this study. The basis of this device is the fluctuation of the U-shaped pipe, which needs to be washed carefully with water and acetone before using and dried with nitrogen gas. The carbonated water device described in Section 2.6 injects the inputfluid to the equipment. The cell volume is 2 cm3. The raw data measured by DMA HPM are imported to themPDS 2000 V3 evaluation unit to estimate the density. The pressure range of the device is 0–140 MPa and its operating temperature range is from −10 to +200 °C. This device can calculate the density in the range of 0–3 g/cm3 with an accuracy of 0.001–0.001 g/cm3 and repeatability of 0.0001–0.00001 g/cm3.
2.8. Ultrasonic agitation system
The Hielscher Ultrasonic Mixer (UP400) was used to disperse and stabilize nanoparticles in saline water. The basis of this device is to convert electric excitation to ultrasound and transfer it tofluids through various sonotrodes. The output power of this unit is 400W. This device has a very wide field of applications. The use of uniform mixing of fluids in nanotechnology and the combination of different types of nanomaterials in basic fluids are among the important applications of this type of agitator. It has various sonotrode sizes, including digital control, touch screen, and automatic data capture. The device efficiency is above 90% and its frequency range is 24 kHz with a control rate of ±1 kHz.

These nanoparticles have a size range of 10–20 nm and a large effective surface area per unit mass, leading to their effective surface adsorption and IFT reduction efficiency. sections.heading: 3.2. Stability of nano-fluids and carbonated nano-fluids and adaptation to water formation
sections.text:
The stability of nano-fluids is very important in the process of EOR. The loss of suspended nanoparticles in the suspension reduces its properties and, in a porousmedium, causes the accumulation of particles and the formation of larger agglomerates, which can reduce permeability and damage the reservoir rock. Therefore, the stability of the nanoparticles is one of the primary conditions for the acceptance of a special nano-fluid for a project. There are various methods for stabilization of nanoparticles, including adding surfactant [66], nano-fluid pH control [67], and ultrasonic vibration [68]. Normally, the stability of nanofluids is greater than other suspension fluids [67]. Besides, factors such as the concentration of nano-particles, diffusers, fluid viscosity, pH, type of nano-particles, nano-particle diameter, and ultrasonic time are affected in this process [69]. Nano-fluid stability testing methods include Sedimentation Balance Method [70], Uv-Vis spectrophotometry [71], Zeta Potential Analysis [72], TEM and SEM [73], the light scattering method [74], the Three Omega Method [75], and the imaging of nanofluid and sediments and evaluating it with direct observation [76]. In these experiments, direct observation and imaging are used for

The figure presents a distilled water based nanofluid. As can be seen, nanofluids are almost homogeneous but agglomerates are observed after 7 days; however, these agglomerates are stable and do not settle. Agglomerates are formed by joining the nanoparticles in an aqueous medium. By an increase in their dimensions, the gravitational force overcomes their stability and makes them precipitate. In an optimal salinity, nanoparticles can be stable for a long time even if the agglomerates are formed and visible [56]. The application of ultrasonic waves causes nanofluid stability to last for several months [77].
The stability of nanoparticles in carbonated nano-fluids is also important. During this time, the IFT that allows the carbonated nanofluids to appear at high pressure and high temperature by the camera device in the droplet was constantly monitored.

sections.heading: 3.3. Measuring the density of carbonated nano-fluids and interfacial tension tests
sections.text:
As mentioned earlier, the density of fluids was measured with an Anton Paar apparatus. To measure the density of fluids and carbonated nano-fluids, the fluidwas injected into the U-shaped tube of the density meter by the carbonating device described in Section 2.6. In this way, the density was calculated and recorded at the temperature and pressure with the accuracy and characteristics described in Section 2.7. In both devices, it took a proper time to balance the flow of liquid and carbon dioxide.
IFT measurement with the IFT400 device is described in Section 2.5. In these experiments, water base fluids were selected as bulk fluid and crude oil as drop. The carbonization of nano-fluids in interfacial tensile experiments was carried out by IFT400 itself. A remarkable point in conducting these experiments is to spend enough time to balance CO2-nanofluids and then spend enough time to balance the dropletbulk system. In fact, after balancing the CO2-nanofluids system, the IFT value displayed by the time-dependent device software, it normally follows an ascending or descending trend until reaching a constant (or fluctuating) value, which is expressed as the IFT of the tested fluid with crude oil.
4. Results and discussion
As mentioned earlier, the densities of the drop and bulk fluids in the pendant drop method are one of the inputs to IFT400 device software. The densities of all fluids used were calculated according to the procedure described in Section 3.3 using the device described in Section 2.7. The densities of fluids used at various pressures and temperatures are given in Table 5.
IFT tests of nano-fluids and carbonated nano-fluids with a water base at a primary concentration and dilution at different temperatures and pressures were performed according to the method described earlier. Table 6 shows the results of these experiments. The values reported in Table 6 were all recorded at the time of the equilibrium of the bulk system and the droplet and after sufficient time and the stability of the IFT. Based on the values in Table 6, studies were conducted on the relationship between IFT and parameters such as the concentration of nanoparticles, base fluid salinity, temperature, and pressure. Figs. 6 to 14 depict the data reported in Table 6 as graphs.
According to the observations of this study, the presence of γ-Al2O3, MgO and TiO2 nanoparticles has more effects on IFT reduction. For example, under identical conditions (at 1000 ppmof nanoparticles, the salinity of 10-times diluted water, the pressure equal to 13.79 MPa, and the temperature of 40 °C), the values obtained from the IFT of the carbonated nano-fluids for γ-Al2O3, MgO and TiO2 are 2.856, 3.319, and 6.437 mN/m, respectively. Based on the results of carbonated nanofluids containing γ-Al2O3 nanoparticles, it can be stated that they are more successful in reducing IFT. It is of note that the size of the nanoparticles as an effective factor in IFT changes is related to the nature of the nanoparticles used. To study the relationship between the concentrations of nanoparticles in reducing the IFT, according to the results reported in Table 6, it is deduced that the reduction of IFT is directly correlated with the concentration of nanoparticles, except for the concentration of MgO carbonated nano-fluids. The 10-times diluted formation water at 40 °C and a pressure of 13.79 MPa resulted in IFT values of 4.818 and 3.319 mN/m for 500 and 1000 ppm nanoparticles, respectively. These IFT values decreased by N38 and 57% in comparison with initial value without the presence of nanoparticles in the system at the stated conditions, which is equal to 7.785 mN/m. Considering the same conditions for TiO2 nanoparticles at concentrations of 500 and 1000 ppm, the values are 8.892 and 6.437 mN/m, respectively while for nano-fluids containing γ-Al2O3 at concentrations of 500 and 1000 ppm, these values are 4.629 and 2.856 mN/m, respectively.
In this study, the effects of temperature, pressure, the concentrations of base fluid and nanoparticles on thewater-oil IFT changes were investigated. Therefore, for better identification of the process of change, the obtained information is presented both in tables and in graphs.
The effect of carbonated nano-fluids on IFT is controlled by at least three mechanisms: first, the presence of nanoparticles, which depends on the type, size, and concentration of nanoparticles [78,79]; second, the mechanism of carbon dioxide solubility in the carbonated system; and third, the soluble ions in base fluid that are related to the type and concentration of ions. Factors such as crude oil composition, temperature, pressure, and time affect all of these three mechanisms. According to these researchers, nanoparticles at the interface between nano-fluid and crude oil form a layer of nanoparticles that results in a less IFT between immersed phases. The function of this layer is very similar to the effect of surfactants in reducing the IFT of water and oil. However, the IFT is proportional to the concentration of nanoparticles dispersed in the nanofluids. As nanoparticles' concentration increases, this mechanism is stronger and the IFT decreases [51,80]. Fig. 15 shows the formation of nanofilms on the interface of the hanging oil droplet in the nanofluid environment in the presence of ions. When nanoparticles are limited in a thin film, they tend to put themselves in tidy layers. In this way, the entropy of the whole suspension increases by increasing the freedom for nanoparticles. As a result, there is a higher pressure on the volume. The shape of the pressure profile depends on the size and shape of the nanoparticles [41]. A thin film consisting of nanoparticles is formed at the interface as a result of the existence of structural disjoining pressure. The origin of this pressure is Brownian motion and electrostatic repulsion between nanoparticles [81]. Aveyard et al. stated that factors such as the concentration and size of nanoparticles, the salinity of the base fluid, temperature, and
interface properties are effective in the preparation of this nanofilm. For example, when the amount (concentration) of nanoparticles increases in the nanofluid, the progression of the film will increase on the interface [81]. Obviously, when the size of the nanoparticles becomes smaller, the effective surface will increase. Besides, when the contact surface is greater, the structure of the nanofluid and oil interface is more effective and further reduces the IFT. Despite these interpretations, the way nanoparticles work in reducing IFT is still unclear and there is no unanimously accepted mechanism in this regard. On this basis, it is necessary to review the effects of salting-in and salting-out. The effect of salting-out is a phenomenon in which organic components with salinity are more likely to move in the petroleum phase, while the salting-in effect is reverse of this, i.e. salting-in organic particles tend to dissolve in water. Here, non-organic ions break down the structure of water created around organic molecules, thereby reducing the solubility of organic molecules in the aqueous phase. It can be said that the salting-in effect facilitates the diffusion of the active components of the solvent from the low salt concentration; in other words, in low salinity, the solubility of solvent types of hydrocarbons in crude oil increases in thewater bulk [91–93], leading to a consequent decrease in IFT values. Thismechanism of ions at low concentrations has been developed in a type of smart water injection. In this technique – which is also known as advanced ion management, ion engineering, and low-salinity water injection – soluble ions are programmed and engineered to achieve optimal salinity according to the reservoir conditions. The simplest type of ions engineering is the dilution of salinewater, including seawater and formation water [5,6,47]. This method, in addition to reducing IFT, activates other mechanisms such aswettability alteration, finemobilization, limited release of mixed-wet particles, multi-component ion exchange, and double layer effect [94].

Today, regarding the decline in the growth of oil reservoir exploration and the increase in energy demand, EOR technology has been of great importance to extract more oil from existing oil resources. In this regard, the methods of increasing oil recovery using chemical agents according to reservoir conditions have provided very promising and encouraging results. By reviewing the projects carried out in this area, it can be concluded that instability in a high-temperature salt environment, chemical degradation due to surface and mechanical stresses, the high price of chemicals given the need for a significant amount of matter, low penetration rate in small cavities, and unwanted adsorption of material are the most important challenges in this process. To date, nanomaterials including silica, titanium dioxide, zinc oxide, and graphene have been used singly or mixed with chemicals for solving these problems. Overally, the results of the present study show that using nanoparticles can reduce existing problems to an acceptable level and lead to a further increase in oil recovery.
5. Conclusion and recommendation
In the present study, a series of interfacial tension (IFT) tests were carried out to reduce IFT of oil and injected phase. In general, the results show that the combination of EOR methods by nanoparticles and carbonated water reinforces this mechanism. According to the results:
• Reduced IFT in the carbonated nano-fluids combination method is controlled by at least three mechanisms related to nanoparticles, carbon dioxide, and base fluid dissolved ions. • The mechanisms may enhance further, so increasing the concentration of nanoparticles in addition to strengthening the mechanism of nano-fluids in reducing IFTwith the increase of solubility of carbon dioxide also strengthens the carbonated water mechanisms. • The lowest IFT was obtained by carbonated γ-Al2O3 nano-fluid at a pressure of 13.79 MPa, a temperature of 40 °C, a concentration of 1000 ppm of nanoparticles, and a salinity of 10 times dilution of the base fluid. • The IFT between carbonated nano-fluids and crude oil shows a direct relationshipwith the temperature and salinity of the basefluid and reverse relationship with the concentration of nanoparticles and the pressure. These relations are affected by carbon dioxide solubility and strengthening of themechanism of nanoparticles at high concentrations and also ions performance in high and low concentrations.
As a hint for future studies, it is suggested studying the effects of carbonated nano-fluids on the wettability of the reservoir rock and performing imbibition and flooding tests for obtaining the recovery factor.
In addition, advantages associated with nanoparticles, despite the great challenges to cover all aspects of the applications of nanoparticles, should be explored further. For example, the percentage of injected
nanoparticles deposited in the porous media must be taken into account. These nanoparticles remain in place for many years. In this regard, no study has been conducted on their long-term environmental effects. Also, by introducing nanoparticles for oil recovery, all aspects of using nanomaterials should be fully evaluated and understood. Furthermore, groundwater contamination with synthesized nanoparticles should be considered as a drawback of using these particles.
